nodes.bodyText: This is something we wanted to avoid, to modify SPI for this.
Do you have an idea how to inject Session properties to CachingJdbcClient ?
In the same way they are provided to JdbcConnector, with Set<SessionPropertiesProvider> sessionProperties
It has to be done for all caches, not only columns.

It has to be done for all caches, not only columns.

@kokosing do you have a usecase in mind?
Please do not inline key as this approach makes this line do one thing more (build key) in addition to 2 already existing: Get and Load, but which we cannot split.

Why protected?
What about other build...CacheKey?
nit: cacheKey -> key
maybe inline .map with next line?
It will become less readable
do you really need copyOf?
Nope. Just being defensive here.
Could you please remove it? You don't expect 'changes from outside' and everything is under your control.
cachingJdbcClient could not be shared between tests. Please extract it to @BeforeMethod.
Why not?
Ok, I see, It can, but I think it's does not worth to reuse stateful object under test between different methods. wdyt?
containsExactlyInAnyOrder
dropTable(phantomTable);
dropTable(phantomTable);
dropTable(phantomTable);
Won't work here. If I don't drop table via cachingJdbcClient then cache won't be invalidated

I was thinking to avoid to even bind CachingJdbcClient in guice, so there would be no question about the way the cache is used in such case. However, I think that might be ok. All I would like to see to to write a unit test where two threads are using disabled CachingJdbcClient and none is waiting for the other.
Please either separate that to different commit or mention this in the commit message.

I am concerned about the overhead of Caching client when caching is not enabled (iteration over session properties and stuff).
I think would be much better to "unbind" this on Guice level. (Should go as a seapate commit.:)

I'm not because I've measured it and it adds the overhead of around 25 nanoseconds (since we are iterating only over catalog properties and retrieving session property is just taking it from a map and decoding (which is basically casting to a given type)

It is not only about overhead, but also about correctness. In case there is a bug in caching we don't have a kill switch as we always do "caching". However this could go as a separate PR (or postponed until the moment we learn it is an issue).
I've tested that cache can be disabled entirely (there is always a load)
What about two concurrent load for the same key? Is this synchronized?
The concurrent hash map implementation built by CacheBuilder. I don't see a reason to test for concurrency here (it should be covered in Guava).
new TableHandleCacheKey(session, schemaTableName)? Same for others. Or TableHandleCacheKey.create(session, schemaTableName)
Latter is not possible (I'd need to pass Set)
undo rename?
what when key.schemaName.isEmpty()? How that can happen?
nothing will be invalidated
use io.prestosql.testing.sql.TestTable#randomTableSuffix

createCachingJdbcClient(CACHE_MISSING, CACHE_ENABLED)? Does it make sense to have cache with cache missing enabled and entire cache disabled? Maybe you could have 3 dedicated methods instead of true, true paremeters? Or instead of cachingEnabled you can pass FOREVER or NEVER. Also we are missing tests for refreshes (REFRESH_AFTER_100_MS).

Can you please have two sessions (two users) cache table for both users and then when table is dropped in Presto both caches got invalidated. Also you can have third user to verify that other table do not get invalidated (optional).
Same goes to other tests like that.
Can you please add tests for drop and create for table and schema.
Actually, I don't know why why are invalidating here.
Idk either. I'll remove that.
You also need to handle session properties for schemaNamesCache and tableNamesCache.
I do.
Can it be private?
#6167 (comment)

this should be metadataCachingTtl.toMillis() == 0, since cache is configured with 1 ms precision
extract common variable to emphasize this must be the same thing

I don't know all custom connectors that are out there.

Assuming  eb3fc50#r534067384, we should not be worried. Notice that we cache only operations that could take much longer.

I believe this is redundant, but we should do 00d7b7b instead
("Add safeguards in table handles cache in JDBC")

This should be separate commit, as this does not "fix cache invalidation" -- the invalidation here was correct.
In fact, I think this is an unnecessary complexity and i would rather not have this change.
(same for other table/schema level invalidations)
Can session property have a null value?
it turns out that yes - in Oracle connector. I've fixed that.
@wendigo if null is possible then toImmutableMap will fail. Will you fix it?
It is fixed, already. See NULL_MARKER
I've added a singleton object that marks that value is null
Why?
That's a good question. Some of the set up methods in tests throws with "Unrecognized session property" when copying from TPCH to target catalog.
This sounds like a bug and can mask other bugs. What was the exact failure?
Just make this return Object
I see this marked resolved, but i do not see this resolved. Did you want to reply here why not doing this?
Not pushed yet
revert "protected", the class is final

make defensive copy to ensure class immutability
(same for others)

i believe JDBC connectors do not support transactions, so "transaction" is actually per query cache.
As such, there is no way to change session properties during a transaction, so you can avoid overheader and pass empty set here (with appropriate explanatory comment in the code)
ZERO
This field is not used in this commit, so I would squash this commit with the commit that uses that.
comment is not needed
Maybe you can add a method JdbcOutputTableHandle#getSchemaTableName()
I would squash that with the commit that is using this.

Not. Would you like me to add that?

no comment is needed
